moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nc3: Probably my favorite opening as white
moves.3. f4: A bit risky due to the bishop eyeing down the a7-g1 diagonal but I can't resist Vienna's Gambit
moves.3... Qf6: Very odd, later seems just as a disrespectful move, now I can't take fxe5
moves.4. Nd5: Giving the queen something to think about
moves.4... Qd6: Better was simply retreating to d8
moves.5... g6 6. Nf3 exf4: Weakening move, now I can conquer the center and go on with my attack
moves.7. d4 Bb4+ 8. c3 Ba5 9. Bxf4 Qc6 10. Bg5: Already considering mating possibilities, here I thought about exchanging my d5 knight with opponent's g8 knight and then stick my bishop and queen into d8 and e7. It didn't work exactly as planned and here I was looking at an unpleasant move from my opponent
moves.10... f5: I didn't expect this but felt that I can even sacrifice the d5 knight to fuel the attack if 11. ... fxe4 and 12. ... Qxd5
moves.12... Qxe4+ 13. Qxe4+ fxe4 14. Ne5: All my minor pieces are in the hunt
moves.14... d6 15. Nf7: I calculated this for a couple of minutes and proudly presented the knight
moves.15... Kxf7 16. Nxc7+ Kg7 17. O-O Bxc7: Rash decision, had to play 17. ... Bf5 to block the mate
moves.18. Rf7#: Beautiful mate after sacrificing two knights, against a higher rated opponent as well!

players: Evaldas Uldinskas  vs. Random Online Player
